elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">The in situ hydrothermal reaction of CuI, NaN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile leads to a new three-dimensional pillared-layer Cu(I)-MOF, [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-I)(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>
</ce:bold>-IPT)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (HIPT<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-[4-(imidazol-1-yl)phenyl]tetrazolate). Interestingly, the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits an unprecedented binodal (4, 8)-connected three-dimensional self-penetrating framework first constructed from [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cationic clusters as 8-connected nodes and in situ generated IPT ligands as 4-connected nodes. Moreover, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is strongly luminescent with green emission (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">em</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>545<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) in the solid-state.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The in situ hydrothermal reaction of CuI, NaN3 and 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile leads to a new three-dimensional pillared-layer Cu(I)-MOF, [Cu2(μ 3-I)(μ  5 -IPT)]n (1) (HIPT=5-[4-(imidazol-1-yl)phenyl]tetrazolate). Interestingly, the structure of 1 exhibits an unprecedented binodal (4, 8)-connected three-dimensional self-penetrating framework first constructed from [Cu4I2]2+ cationic clusters as 8-connected nodes and in situ generated IPT ligands as 4-connected nodes. Moreover, 1 is strongly luminescent with green emission (λ em =545nm) in the solid-state.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0010">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">A new 3D pillared-layer metal–organic framework first formed from [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cationic cluster and in situ generated tetrazole ligand has been synthesized and characterized, which exhibits an unprecedented (4, 8)-connected self-penetrating net with (4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">18</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>) topology. Moreover, Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is intense luminescent with green emission at room temperature.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:link id="lk0030" locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A new 3D pillared-layer metal-organic framework first formed from [Cu4I2]2+ cationic cluster and in situ generated tetrazole ligand has been synthesized and characterized, which exhibits an unprecedented (4, 8)-connected self-penetrating net with (43⋅63)2(46⋅618⋅84) topology. Moreover, Complex 1 is intense luminescent with green emission at room temperature.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0015">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0055" view="all">
<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="u0005">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">A new 3D self-penetrating pillared-layer Cu-MOF has been described.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0010">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The complex displays the first example of (4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">18</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>) topology.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0015">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The complex consists of cationic [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cluster and in situ generated tetrazole ligand.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0020">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The complex has good green luminescent property.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ A new 3D self-penetrating pillared-layer Cu-MOF has been described.   ⋅ The complex displays the first example of (43⋅63)2(46⋅618⋅84) topology.   ⋅ The complex consists of cationic [Cu4I2]2+ cluster and in situ generated tetrazole ligand.   ⋅ The complex has good green luminescent property.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">A new 3D self-penetrating pillared-layer Cu-MOF has been described.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The complex displays the first example of (4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">18</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>) topology.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The complex consists of cationic [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cluster and in situ generated tetrazole ligand.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The complex has good green luminescent property.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Recently, the burgeoning interest in the domain of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), particularly entangled MOFs, has been rapidly expanding because of their potential application used as functional crystalline materials in many areas , and more importantly, due to their inherent esthetic appeal and complicated network topological features . Up to now, most of the topology nets of MOFs which have been exhibited are only involved in three-, four-, or six-connected topologies owing to the limits of the usable coordination number of the metal centers , so further significant challenging work should be done in the topic of highly connected MOFs. The most effective route is rational employing of the ploynuclear metal clusters to replace general metal ions . As is well known, the current prominent Cu(I)-I clusters have been proved to be ideal building-blocks to assemble highly connected MOFs owing to their extensive connectivity and structural diversity . More importantly, they can propagate the structural diversity and physical properties to the MOFs constructed via suitable organic linking ligands. The structural diversity of [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">m-n</ce:sup> clusters can be assigned to the linking versatility of the iodine anion, such as diverse cationic (m<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>n), anionic (m<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>n) and neutral (m<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>n) clusters . The neutral Cu(I)-I clusters can be easily bridged via organic ligands to present CuI coordination polymers, whereas the anionic Cu(I)-I clusters can also assemble into organic-templated CuI frameworks. For the cationic Cu(I)-I clusters, the investigation of the corresponding MOFs is still less developed owning to assembly difficulties [], so much more work for the cationic Cu(I)-I cluster-based MOFs should be done. Moreover, the organic bridging ligands as important build-blocks also play an important role in forming the resulting coordination framework . 5-[4-(imidazol-1-yl)phenyl]tetrazolate (HIPT) as an excellent build-block, which possesses both one imidazole group and one tetrazole group, has been previously employed in the construction of coordination polymer , all of which show that HIPT ligand as a good multidentate ligand possesses the excellent coordinated capacity. Especially, the tetrazole group can also effectively obtained through a [3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2] cycloaddition reaction between organic nitrile and NaN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in the presence of Lewis acid , whereas HIPT has not been well exhibited in the synthesized coordination polymers due to many factors influencing the assembly process. To our knowledge, the analogous chemistry of Cu(I)-MOF bearing IPT ligand has never been explored. Thus, based on the aforementioned discussions and the continuation of our previous investigations on the Cu(I)-MOFs and in situ metal/ligand reactions , we have successfully constructed a novel Cu(I)-MOF [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-I)(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-IPT)]n (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) containing [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cationic cluster and IPT ligands, which exhibits an intriguing architecture and intense green emission.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
A new 3D self-penetrating pillared-layer Cu-MOF has been described.

The complex displays the first example of (43⋅63)2(46⋅618⋅84) topology.

The complex consists of cationic [Cu4I2]2+ cluster and in situ generated tetrazole ligand.

The complex has good green luminescent property.

Recently, the burgeoning interest in the domain of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), particularly entangled MOFs, has been rapidly expanding because of their potential application used as functional crystalline materials in many areas , and more importantly, due to their inherent esthetic appeal and complicated network topological features . Up to now, most of the topology nets of MOFs which have been exhibited are only involved in three-, four-, or six-connected topologies owing to the limits of the usable coordination number of the metal centers , so further significant challenging work should be done in the topic of highly connected MOFs. The most effective route is rational employing of the ploynuclear metal clusters to replace general metal ions . As is well known, the current prominent Cu(I)-I clusters have been proved to be ideal building-blocks to assemble highly connected MOFs owing to their extensive connectivity and structural diversity . More importantly, they can propagate the structural diversity and physical properties to the MOFs constructed via suitable organic linking ligands. The structural diversity of [CumIn]m-n clusters can be assigned to the linking versatility of the iodine anion, such as diverse cationic (m>n), anionic (m<n) and neutral (m=n) clusters . The neutral Cu(I)-I clusters can be easily bridged via organic ligands to present CuI coordination polymers, whereas the anionic Cu(I)-I clusters can also assemble into organic-templated CuI frameworks. For the cationic Cu(I)-I clusters, the investigation of the corresponding MOFs is still less developed owning to assembly difficulties [], so much more work for the cationic Cu(I)-I cluster-based MOFs should be done. Moreover, the organic bridging ligands as important build-blocks also play an important role in forming the resulting coordination framework . 5-[4-(imidazol-1-yl)phenyl]tetrazolate (HIPT) as an excellent build-block, which possesses both one imidazole group and one tetrazole group, has been previously employed in the construction of coordination polymer , all of which show that HIPT ligand as a good multidentate ligand possesses the excellent coordinated capacity. Especially, the tetrazole group can also effectively obtained through a [3+2] cycloaddition reaction between organic nitrile and NaN3 in the presence of Lewis acid , whereas HIPT has not been well exhibited in the synthesized coordination polymers due to many factors influencing the assembly process. To our knowledge, the analogous chemistry of Cu(I)-MOF bearing IPT ligand has never been explored. Thus, based on the aforementioned discussions and the continuation of our previous investigations on the Cu(I)-MOFs and in situ metal/ligand reactions , we have successfully constructed a novel Cu(I)-MOF [Cu2(μ 3-I)(μ 5-IPT)]n (1) containing [Cu4I2]2+ cationic cluster and IPT ligands, which exhibits an intriguing architecture and intense green emission.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">The colorless block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were easily produced via the in situ hydrothermal reaction of CuI, NaN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, and 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile in H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O at 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days . Single-crystal X-ray analysis shows that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in an orthorhombic space group <ce:italic>Pbca</ce:italic>
, and presents an unprecedented (4, 8)-connected 3D self-penetrating pillared-layer framework bearing the [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cationic cluster. In the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, there exist two crystallographic independent Cu(I) ions, one iodine anion, and one IPT ligand (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). All the Cu(I) ions are four-coordinated and adopt distorted tetrahedral configurations. Each Cu1 atom is coordinated to one <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-I anion, one imidazole N-atom from one <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-IPT ligand and two tetrazole N-atoms from other two different <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-IPT ligands. The Cu2 atom is coordinated to two <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-I anions and two tetrazole N-atoms from two different <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-IPT ligands. The Cu<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>I and Cu<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bond lengths are of 2.6357(16)–2.7579(18) Å and 2.000(5)–2.101(4) Å, respectively, and the corresponding angles around the two Cu(I) atoms vary in the range of 100.21(13)–132.92(19)° (Table S1), all of which coincide with those reported in the literature.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The colorless block crystals of 1 were easily produced via the in situ hydrothermal reaction of CuI, NaN3, and 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile in H2O at 120°C for 3days . Single-crystal X-ray analysis shows that 1 crystallizes in an orthorhombic space group Pbca , and presents an unprecedented (4, 8)-connected 3D self-penetrating pillared-layer framework bearing the [Cu4I2]2+ cationic cluster. In the asymmetric unit of 1, there exist two crystallographic independent Cu(I) ions, one iodine anion, and one IPT ligand ( ). All the Cu(I) ions are four-coordinated and adopt distorted tetrahedral configurations. Each Cu1 atom is coordinated to one μ 3-I anion, one imidazole N-atom from one μ 5-IPT ligand and two tetrazole N-atoms from other two different μ 5-IPT ligands. The Cu2 atom is coordinated to two μ 3-I anions and two tetrazole N-atoms from two different μ 5-IPT ligands. The CuI and CuN bond lengths are of 2.6357(16)-2.7579(18) Å and 2.000(5)-2.101(4) Å, respectively, and the corresponding angles around the two Cu(I) atoms vary in the range of 100.21(13)-132.92(19)° (Table S1), all of which coincide with those reported in the literature.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Moreover, each <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-I anion ligates three adjacent Cu(I) ions to produce a rare [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cationic cluster (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>, Cu1⋯Cu1 7.7191(36) Å, Cu2⋯Cu2 3.3685(21) Å). Interestingly, the [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cationic clusters locate on a crystallographic inverse center, displaying a distinct parallelogram of four Cu(I) ions. The Cu⋯Cu distances for each edge of 4.6618(30) Å and 3.7058(20) Å, respectively, and the smaller Cu2⋯Cu1⋯Cu2 angle of 45.729(19)°. The two <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-I anions deviated from the aforementioned (Cu)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> plane with a deviation of 1.3166 and −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1.3166<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. Further, these [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cationic clusters are linked via the <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-IPT ligands to present a distinct three-dimensional pillared-layer metal–organic framework, which is delimited through the two-dimensional corrugated metal inorganic–organic layers (I–Cu-tetrazole) paralleling to the <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane and the fragments of (1H-imidazole1)phenyl of the <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-IPT ligands via covalent bonds (C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C) and coordination bonds (Cu–N<ce:inf loc="post">imidazole</ce:inf>) along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). Notably, the Cu2 atoms in the two-dimensional layer distribute in an approximate local plane whereas the Cu1 atoms in two different parallel planes, with a separated interlayer distance of 1.860<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å between the (Cu1)<ce:inf loc="post">n/2</ce:inf> and (Cu2)<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> planes, while 3.720<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å between the two (Cu1)<ce:inf loc="post">n/2</ce:inf> planes. Additionally, the above corrugated layers are packed in parallel positions in a -A-A- model along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis, with the adjacent interlayer distance of 10.252<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, (Cu2)<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> planes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Moreover, each μ 3-I anion ligates three adjacent Cu(I) ions to produce a rare [Cu4I2]2+ cationic cluster ( , Cu1⋯Cu1 7.7191(36) Å, Cu2⋯Cu2 3.3685(21) Å). Interestingly, the [Cu4I2]2+ cationic clusters locate on a crystallographic inverse center, displaying a distinct parallelogram of four Cu(I) ions. The Cu⋯Cu distances for each edge of 4.6618(30) Å and 3.7058(20) Å, respectively, and the smaller Cu2⋯Cu1⋯Cu2 angle of 45.729(19)°. The two μ 3-I anions deviated from the aforementioned (Cu)4 plane with a deviation of 1.3166 and -1.3166Å, respectively. Further, these [Cu4I2]2+ cationic clusters are linked via the μ 5-IPT ligands to present a distinct three-dimensional pillared-layer metal-organic framework, which is delimited through the two-dimensional corrugated metal inorganic-organic layers (I-Cu-tetrazole) paralleling to the ab plane and the fragments of (1H-imidazole1)phenyl of the μ 5-IPT ligands via covalent bonds (CC) and coordination bonds (Cu-Nimidazole) along the b axis ( ). Notably, the Cu2 atoms in the two-dimensional layer distribute in an approximate local plane whereas the Cu1 atoms in two different parallel planes, with a separated interlayer distance of 1.860Å between the (Cu1)n/2 and (Cu2)n planes, while 3.720Å between the two (Cu1)n/2 planes. Additionally, the above corrugated layers are packed in parallel positions in a -A-A- model along the b-axis, with the adjacent interlayer distance of 10.252Å, (Cu2)n planes.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Most interestingly, the above three-dimensional pillared-layer framework can be classified as an unprecedented binodal (4, 8)-connected topological net with the Point (Schläfli) symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">18</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>) evaluated via TOPOS, which is completely different from the classical <ce:italic>
<ce:bold>flu</ce:bold>
</ce:italic> [] and <ce:italic>
<ce:bold>scu</ce:bold>
</ce:italic> net , and is also a novel example of the binodal (4, 8)-connected topological net (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). Noticeably, in the aforementioned binodal network, each in situ generated IPT ligand can be regarded as a 4-connected node for it bridges four [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cationic clusters (the Schläfli symbol is (4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>), the extended point symbol is [4.6(2)·4.6(2)·4.6(4)]), and the [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cationic cluster can be considered as a 8-connected node since it links eight IPT ligands (the Schläfli symbol is (4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">18</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>), the extended point symbol is [4.4.4.4.4.4.6.6.6.6.6.6.6.6.6(2).6(2).6(2).6(2).6(2).6(2).6(4).6(4).6(4).6(4).8(2).8(20).8(24).8(40)]). Furthermore, the above topological network presents an intriguing architecture of self-penetration, which was produced through the catenation occurring in two 6-membered circuits (). To our knowledge, such a binodal (4, 8)-connected self-penetrating topological net has not been reported yet, which is obviously different from the (4, 8)-connected topological nets reported [].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Most interestingly, the above three-dimensional pillared-layer framework can be classified as an unprecedented binodal (4, 8)-connected topological net with the Point (Schläfli) symbol of (43⋅63)2(46⋅618⋅84) evaluated via TOPOS, which is completely different from the classical  flu  [] and  scu  net , and is also a novel example of the binodal (4, 8)-connected topological net ( ). Noticeably, in the aforementioned binodal network, each in situ generated IPT ligand can be regarded as a 4-connected node for it bridges four [Cu4I2]2+ cationic clusters (the Schläfli symbol is (43⋅63), the extended point symbol is [4.6(2)⋅4.6(2)⋅4.6(4)]), and the [Cu4I2]2+ cationic cluster can be considered as a 8-connected node since it links eight IPT ligands (the Schläfli symbol is (46⋅618⋅84), the extended point symbol is [4.4.4.4.4.4.6.6.6.6.6.6.6.6.6(2).6(2).6(2).6(2).6(2).6(2).6(4).6(4).6(4).6(4).8(2).8(20).8(24).8(40)]). Furthermore, the above topological network presents an intriguing architecture of self-penetration, which was produced through the catenation occurring in two 6-membered circuits (). To our knowledge, such a binodal (4, 8)-connected self-penetrating topological net has not been reported yet, which is obviously different from the (4, 8)-connected topological nets reported [].

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The IR spectra of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> further corroborates the absence of a peak at around 2200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, which presents that the cyano group of 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile has turned into the tetrazole group of HIPT ligand with several symbolic tetrazolyl group peaks at 1447, and 1382<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>. The C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N stretching vibration of imidazolyl group of HIPT ligand was located at 1539<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>. All the above IR spectra attribution coincides with the structural determination based on the single crystal X-ray diffraction.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The IR spectra of complex 1 further corroborates the absence of a peak at around 2200cm-1, which presents that the cyano group of 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile has turned into the tetrazole group of HIPT ligand with several symbolic tetrazolyl group peaks at 1447, and 1382cm-1. The CN stretching vibration of imidazolyl group of HIPT ligand was located at 1539cm-1. All the above IR spectra attribution coincides with the structural determination based on the single crystal X-ray diffraction.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The luminescent metal–organic frameworks bearing the closed <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> shell structure have been widely investigated for their potential applications as functional luminescent materials . We here studied the solid-state luminescent property of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at room temperature. As depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>, an intense broad green emission band was observed at 545<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>290<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The reported solid free HIPT ligand has three intense broad fluorescent emission bands centered at around 416, 436, and 466<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>367<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm), which can be assigned to the ligand-centered <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>*<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>*<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> emissions []. Nevertheless, the conformation of IPT ligand in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> abruptly changes owing to the coordination interaction. The dihedral angles between the N-heterocycles and benzene ring are 27.57° for tetrazole ring, 30.13° for imidazole ring, respectively, so the significant red shift emission peak of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> should not be assigned to ligand-centered emission. In comparison with the reported luminescence properties of Cu-I cluster-based complexes bearing N-heterocyclic ligands, the emission peak of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> should be tentatively assigned to the combined consequences of the LLCT (ligand to ligand charge transfer) transition and MLCT (metal to ligand charge transfer) transition .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The luminescent metal-organic frameworks bearing the closed d 10 shell structure have been widely investigated for their potential applications as functional luminescent materials . We here studied the solid-state luminescent property of 1 at room temperature. As depicted in  , an intense broad green emission band was observed at 545nm (λ ex =290nm) for 1. The reported solid free HIPT ligand has three intense broad fluorescent emission bands centered at around 416, 436, and 466nm (λ ex =367nm), which can be assigned to the ligand-centered π*→ n and π*→ π emissions []. Nevertheless, the conformation of IPT ligand in 1 abruptly changes owing to the coordination interaction. The dihedral angles between the N-heterocycles and benzene ring are 27.57° for tetrazole ring, 30.13° for imidazole ring, respectively, so the significant red shift emission peak of 1 should not be assigned to ligand-centered emission. In comparison with the reported luminescence properties of Cu-I cluster-based complexes bearing N-heterocyclic ligands, the emission peak of 1 should be tentatively assigned to the combined consequences of the LLCT (ligand to ligand charge transfer) transition and MLCT (metal to ligand charge transfer) transition .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Overall, we have successfully synthesized a novel Cu(I)-I cluster-based metal–organic framework containing auxiliary IPT ligands via a simultaneous in situ metal/ligand and self-assembly reaction of 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile used as ligand precursor under hydrothermal condition. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> demonstrates an unprecedented binodal (4, 8)-connected three-dimensional pillared-layer framework with (4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">18</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>) topology, which holding the rare [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cationic clusters and self-penetrating entanglement. The successful synthesis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> will not only deepen our understanding of the Cu(I)-I clusters and topology diversity, but also provide a promising strategy for in situ assembly of novel intriguing architectures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Overall, we have successfully synthesized a novel Cu(I)-I cluster-based metal-organic framework containing auxiliary IPT ligands via a simultaneous in situ metal/ligand and self-assembly reaction of 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile used as ligand precursor under hydrothermal condition. 1 demonstrates an unprecedented binodal (4, 8)-connected three-dimensional pillared-layer framework with (43⋅63)2(46⋅618⋅84) topology, which holding the rare [Cu4I2]2+ cationic clusters and self-penetrating entanglement. The successful synthesis of 1 will not only deepen our understanding of the Cu(I)-I clusters and topology diversity, but also provide a promising strategy for in situ assembly of novel intriguing architectures.

Supplementary data

    Supplementary material 1.        Supplementary material 2.        Supplementary material 3.     

Supplementary data

The supplementary crystallographic data (CCDC No. 1062912) for complex 1 can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Supplementary data to this article can be found online at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.inoche.2015.06.034.

elements.content: <ce:simple-para id="sp0045" view="all">Synthesis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: A mixture of CuI (0.0381<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), NaN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.0065<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile (0.0169<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was sealed in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. The reactor was heated to 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days, and then slowly cooled down to room temperature. Colorless block crystals were isolated in 53% yield (based on CuI). C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>ICu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (465.20): Calc. C, 26.28; H, 1.84; N, 25.54; Found C, 26.21; H, 1.87; N, 25.61%. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>): 3442(br), 1616(m), 1539(s), 1512(m), 1494(w), 1447(w), 1398(w), 1382(w), 1305(m), 1263(w), 1232(w), 1187(w), 1063(m), 953(w), 823(m), 749(m), 718(w), 652(w), 496(w).</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of 1: A mixture of CuI (0.0381g, 0.2mmol), NaN3 (0.0065g, 0.1mmol), 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile (0.0169g, 0.1mmol) and H2O (15mL) was sealed in a 25mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. The reactor was heated to 120°C for 3days, and then slowly cooled down to room temperature. Colorless block crystals were isolated in 53% yield (based on CuI). C10H7N6ICu2 (465.20): Calc. C, 26.28; H, 1.84; N, 25.54; Found C, 26.21; H, 1.87; N, 25.61%. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3442(br), 1616(m), 1539(s), 1512(m), 1494(w), 1447(w), 1398(w), 1382(w), 1305(m), 1263(w), 1232(w), 1187(w), 1063(m), 953(w), 823(m), 749(m), 718(w), 652(w), 496(w).

cln_elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">The in situ hydrothermal reaction of CuI, NaN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile leads to a new three-dimensional pillared-layer Cu(I)-MOF, [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-I)(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>
</ce:bold>-IPT)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (HIPT<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-[4-(imidazol-1-yl)phenyl]tetrazolate). Interestingly, the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits an unprecedented binodal (4, 8)-connected three-dimensional self-penetrating framework first constructed from [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cationic clusters as 8-connected nodes and in situ generated IPT ligands as 4-connected nodes. Moreover, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is strongly luminescent with green emission (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">em</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>545<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) in the solid-state.</ce:simple-para><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The luminescent metal–organic frameworks bearing the closed <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> shell structure have been widely investigated for their potential applications as functional luminescent materials . We here studied the solid-state luminescent property of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at room temperature. As depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>, an intense broad green emission band was observed at 545<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>290<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The reported solid free HIPT ligand has three intense broad fluorescent emission bands centered at around 416, 436, and 466<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>367<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm), which can be assigned to the ligand-centered <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>*<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>*<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> emissions []. Nevertheless, the conformation of IPT ligand in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> abruptly changes owing to the coordination interaction. The dihedral angles between the N-heterocycles and benzene ring are 27.57° for tetrazole ring, 30.13° for imidazole ring, respectively, so the significant red shift emission peak of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> should not be assigned to ligand-centered emission. In comparison with the reported luminescence properties of Cu-I cluster-based complexes bearing N-heterocyclic ligands, the emission peak of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> should be tentatively assigned to the combined consequences of the LLCT (ligand to ligand charge transfer) transition and MLCT (metal to ligand charge transfer) transition .</ce:para><ce:simple-para id="sp0050" view="all">Crystallographic data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>ICu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>r<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>465.20, Orthorhombic <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>bca with <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8.714(6) Å, b<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>13.480(10) Å, c<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>20.447(15) Å, V<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2402(3) Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, Z<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8, <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">calcd.<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:inf>2.573<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg·m<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>in<ce:italic>t</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0477, <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>(000)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1760, <ce:italic>GOF</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.006, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> [<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>2σ</ce:italic> (<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0350, <ce:italic>wR</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (all data)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0867. The structure was solved via direct method and refined using the full-matrix least-squares technique on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> with the SHELXTL program package . CCDC: 1062912.</ce:simple-para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The in situ hydrothermal reaction of CuI, NaN3 and 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile leads to a new three-dimensional pillared-layer Cu(I)-MOF, [Cu2(μ 3-I)(μ  5 -IPT)]n (1) (HIPT=5-[4-(imidazol-1-yl)phenyl]tetrazolate). Interestingly, the structure of 1 exhibits an unprecedented binodal (4, 8)-connected three-dimensional self-penetrating framework first constructed from [Cu4I2]2+ cationic clusters as 8-connected nodes and in situ generated IPT ligands as 4-connected nodes. Moreover, 1 is strongly luminescent with green emission (λ em =545nm) in the solid-state.

The luminescent metal-organic frameworks bearing the closed d 10 shell structure have been widely investigated for their potential applications as functional luminescent materials . We here studied the solid-state luminescent property of 1 at room temperature. As depicted in  , an intense broad green emission band was observed at 545nm (λ ex =290nm) for 1. The reported solid free HIPT ligand has three intense broad fluorescent emission bands centered at around 416, 436, and 466nm (λ ex =367nm), which can be assigned to the ligand-centered π*→ n and π*→ π emissions []. Nevertheless, the conformation of IPT ligand in 1 abruptly changes owing to the coordination interaction. The dihedral angles between the N-heterocycles and benzene ring are 27.57° for tetrazole ring, 30.13° for imidazole ring, respectively, so the significant red shift emission peak of 1 should not be assigned to ligand-centered emission. In comparison with the reported luminescence properties of Cu-I cluster-based complexes bearing N-heterocyclic ligands, the emission peak of 1 should be tentatively assigned to the combined consequences of the LLCT (ligand to ligand charge transfer) transition and MLCT (metal to ligand charge transfer) transition .

Crystallographic data for 1: C10H7N6ICu2, Mr=465.20, Orthorhombic Pbca with a =8.714(6) Å, b=13.480(10) Å, c=20.447(15) Å, V=2402(3) Å3, Z=8, D calcd.= 2.573mg⋅m-3, Rint =0.0477, F(000)=1760, GOF =1.006, R 1 [I > 2σ (I)]=0.0350, wR 2 (all data)=0.0867. The structure was solved via direct method and refined using the full-matrix least-squares technique on F 2 with the SHELXTL program package . CCDC: 1062912.

metadata.title: An unprecedented (4, 8)-connected self-penetrating Cu(I)-MOF constructed from the rare [Cu4I2]2+ cationic cluster and in situ generated tetrazole ligand
